Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering Kunming University of Science and Technology Yunnan 650500 China This research has made significant advancements in the field of high-value bio-oil production, specifically focusing on the synthesis of the rare sugar D-Allose. Notably, synthesizing D-Allose through cellulose pyrolysis has long been challenging due to its high synthetic difficulty, which has limited related studies. By employing a one-pot synthesis approach using Alx-Fey nano-catalysts prepared through a unique cellulose pretreatment method, this experiment successfully achieved efficient generation of D-Allose during rapid pyrolysis. Systematic experimentation demonstrated that at 330 °C with the Al1-Fe5 nano-catalyst, the yield of D-Allose from cellulose pyrolysis reached an impressive 50.69 %, accompanied by a detection of 14.35 % furfural in the bio-oil. This breakthrough not only significantly contributes to the high-value utilization of bio-oil but also provides robust support for further development in this area. Simultaneously, the success of this research extends beyond high-value bio-oil utilization and makes a substantial impact on both the scientific community and industry. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords D-Allose Cellulose pyrolysis Alx-Fey nano-catalyst Bio-oil Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent years, the global energy crisis and the challenges posed by the greenhouse effect have intensified the quest for new renewable energy sources [1]. Against this backdrop, biomass energy has garnered significant research attention owing to its renewability and environmental sustainability [2]. Lignocellulosic biomass, in particular, has emerged as a prominent subject of current research endeavors due to its abundant availability and considerable potential for energy utilization [3]. Lignocellulose predominantly consists of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin, with cellulose being the principal constituent, representing 40–80 % of the total mass [4]. Consequently, this study is aimed at thoroughly investigating the pathways for the high-value utilization of cellulose, with a specific focus on the production of high-value-added compounds during its pyrolysis, such as levoglucose, furfural, and D-Allose [5]. As a unique chiral sugar molecule, D-Allose is a rare sugar in nature, distinguished from D-glucose by its configuration at the C-3 position [6]. This differential isomerism endows D-Allose with a molecular structure that confers upon it a relatively high sweetness, approximately 70 % that of sucrose. However, its caloric value is remarkably low, at only 10 % of that of glucose [7]. Recognizing these attributes, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) officially approved D-Allose as a safe sucrose alternative in 2014 [8]. The application of D-Allose is rapidly expanding across various fields. Scientific research has indicated that D-Allose possesses potential anticancer properties, capable of disrupting the growth and metastasis of cancer cells, positioning it as a candidate for a novel cancer therapeutic [9]. Furthermore, its potential in the treatment of diabetes and other diseases has garnered significant interest [10]. Beyond its medical applications, D-Allose also contributes to skin health and the mitigation of the ageing process, frequently utilized as a moisturizer and antioxidant in cosmetics and skin care products [11]. These diverse applications highlight the broad potential of D-Allose, ensuring that its study and utilization are at the forefront of scientific inquiry. Despite extensive research spanning nearly a century, the synthesis of D-Allose continues to confront several challenges [12]. These include the difficulty of purification due to low yields, the risk of contamination in chemical synthesis processes, and the complex and often uncontrollable nature of pyrolysis products [13]. For instance, Ganqiao Ran et al. successfully achieved a one-step preparation of immobilized dehydrogenase enzyme (DTE)-polyhydroxy fatty acid ester (PHA) beads through an innovative biosynthetic strategy. This strategy utilized a recombinant endotoxin-free Clearcoli strain as the host, fusing the DTE gene sequence to the N-terminus of the PHA synthase gene to enable efficient expression and immobilization of DTE. The resulting DTE-PHA microspheres exhibited excellent catalytic performance, particularly in the conversion of D-fructose to D-Allose, with a specific activity of 649.3 U/g and a conversion efficiency of 33 % [14]. However, the sensitivity of the free enzyme to fluctuations in ambient temperature and pH restricts its stability and reusability in industrial applications. Additionally, Rameshwari Verma et al. discovered that wheat straw acid-washed with HCl could yield up to 22.18 % D-Allose through pyrolysis following acid-washing pretreatment with HCl, HF, or a combination of both [15]. However, the relatively low D-Allose content, compounded by the difficulty of effectively separating D-Allose from D-fructose due to their C3-differential isomerism, renders conventional methods challenging and escalates production costs and technical complexity. In another study, Dongyu Chen et al. successfully generated D-Allose through acid-washing pretreatment of sweet sorghum bagasse, albeit with a yield of only 15.3 % [16]. These efforts underscore the ongoing need for more efficient and economical methods to synthesize D-Allose. In aggregate, these challenges collectively restrict the large-scale production and application of D-Allose. To transcend these limitations, our study implemented a suite of innovative pretreatment methods, encompassing low-temperature freezing and ultrasound-assisted chemical treatment. Furthermore, we employed Al1-Fe5 nanocatalysts to facilitate the isomerization of hydroxyl groups at the C-3 position of cellulose. This strategy culminated in the highly efficient synthesis of D-Allose, achieving a yield of 50.69 %. Additionally, the compositional analysis of the bio-oil revealed a 14.35 % furfural content. These innovative approaches present new opportunities for enhancing the synthesis efficiency and diminishing the production costs associated with D-Allose. They also introduce novel avenues for the sustainable exploitation of biomass resources and the manufacturing of bio-based chemicals, contributing to the advancement of green chemistry and sustainable development. 2 Experimental 2.1 Feedstock The raw materials employed in this study comprised microcrystalline cellulose with a particle size of 90 µm. The chemicals utilized for synthesizing the catalysts included iron nitrate hydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O), aluminium nitrate hydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O), urea (CO(NH2)2), and methanol (CH3OH). Furthermore, sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and concentrated phosphoric acid (H3PO4) were utilized in the experimental process to prepare solutions to soak cellulose and catalysts methodically. These chemicals were of high purity grade and were procured from Aladdin (Shanghai, China). The experiments did not require additional purification of the raw materials and chemicals. Deionized water was prepared using a UPT-1-10T purification system (Chengdu, China) and used to prepare all solutions. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Alx-Fey nano-catalysts in this study were synthesized through the hydrothermal method [17]. The synthesis procedure involved several steps: Initially, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O, and CO(NH2)2 were measured according to predetermined molar ratios (0:5:1, 1:1:1, 1:3:1, 1:5:1, 1:7:1, and 5:1:1) and dissolved in an appropriate volume of methanol. The mixture of metal salts was magnetically stirred for 40 min to ensure complete dissolution and a homogeneous mixture. Subsequently, the resulting mixed metal salt solution was transferred into an autoclave reactor, placed in a muffle furnace, and heated at 150 °C for 12 h for the reaction. The solution was then naturally cooled to room temperature. The obtained slurry was washed 2-3 times with distilled water and filtered by pumping. The solid sample obtained from filtration was dried in a constant temperature drying oven at 80 °C for 10 h. The resulting catalysts were denoted as Alx-Fey nano-catalysts, where x and y took 0, 1, 5, and 1, 3, 5, 7, respectively. 2.3 Characterization A Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FT-IR, Is50, U.S.A.) from Nicorette Instruments Inc. was used in the experiments to analyze the pretreated cellulose, catalysts and bio-char for functional groups. A thermogravimetric analyzer (TG-DTG, 1600H, Switzerland) from Mettler Switzerland was used to analyze the cellulose and catalyst; a scanning electron microscope (SEM, ZEISS Sigma 300, Germany) and an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku Ultima IV, Japan) were used to analyze the surface morphology of the cellulose, the pretreated cellulose, catalyst, and the bio-char generated by cellulose pyrolysis. The surface morphology of cellulose, pretreated cellulose, catalyst, and cellulose pyrolysis-generated bio-char was characterized. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo 114 Scientific ESCALAB Xi+, U.S.A.) was applied to analyze the catalyst and the bio-char generated from cellulose pyrolysis, and all spectra were calibrated by 284.8 eV for the carbon (C1s) peak. The acidity of the catalyst was determined by an ammonia-programmed thermal desorption (NH3-TPD) test performed in a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. The ammonia signal was recorded online by a TCD. detector. In the NH3-TPD experiments, 50–100 mg of sample was taken in a reaction tube, warmed from room temperature to 150 °C at 10 °C/min for drying preconditioning, purged by He gas flow (30–50 mL/min) for 1 h, cooled to 50 °C, passed through a 10 % NH3/He mixture (30–50 mL/min) for 1 h to saturation, switched He gas flow (30–50 mL/min) for 1 h to remove the weakly physiosorbed NH3 on the surface, and finally, desorption was carried out under He atmosphere at an elevated temperature rate of 10 °C/min up to 800 °C, and TCD detected the stripped gas. The prepared catalysts ' particle size and void measurements were carried out by N2-temperature programmed desorption (N2-TPD) using a Mac Micromeritics, 3Flex, U.S.A. Compositional analyses of bio-oil generated from cellulose pyrolysis were performed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS). The chromatographic column was HP-5MS (30.0 m × 250 μm, 0.25 μm), and the starting temperature was held at 50 °C for 1 min, then increased to 300 °C at a rate of 6 °C/min and held for 5 min. The temperature of the gasification chamber was 300 °C, the transmission line temperature was 300 °C, the carrier gas was helium, the flow rate was 1.0 mL/min, the split ratio was 20:1, and the injection volume was 1 μL. The mass spectrometry conditions were an electron-ion source (E.I. source) with an electron energy of 70 eV, the temperature of the ion source was 230 °C, and the temperature of the quadrupole was 150 °C, the scanning mode was scanning, and the scanning mass range was from 35 to 500 u. 2.4 Pyrolysis experiments The experimental procedure consisted of two primary steps. The first step involved the pretreatment of cellulose and the catalyst. Initially, the cellulose underwent the first pretreatment step by being placed in a refrigerator at -70 °C for 24 h. Subsequently, 2.5 g of pretreated cellulose and 0.5 g of Alx-Fey nano-catalyst, prepared as described in the previous process, were combined in an H3PO4 solution and sonicated at 50 °C for 30 min. The sonicated mixture of cellulose and catalyst was then diafiltrated, and the collected mixture was heated at 110 °C for 10 min to obtain a dehydrated intermediate product. After the dehydrated intermediate product naturally cooled to room temperature, it was immersed in an aqueous sodium hydroxide solution, thoroughly mixed, and subjected to ultrasonication again at 50 °C for 30 min. The treated product underwent another round of filtration and drying, completing the pretreatment step for cellulose and the catalyst. The second step involved the rapid pyrolysis of cellulose. Initially, the homemade pyrolysis unit underwent nitrogen (N2) purging to eliminate air from the unit, ensuring cellulose underwent pyrolysis in a pure N2 atmosphere. After removing the air, the pyrolysis unit was heated to 330 °C. A cellulose and catalyst mixture were swiftly injected at 330 °C to initiate pyrolysis. The apparatus for cellulose pyrolysis is shown in Fig. 1 . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Cellulose pre-treatment In biomass pyrolysis, the pretreatment of cellulose is critical for enhancing pyrolysis efficiency and product selectivity [18]. Initially, applying freezing treatment to cellulose at extremely low temperatures destroys its microstructure through internal stress caused by the formation of ice crystals [19]. This action increases the cellulose's porosity and specific surface area, thereby providing greater accessibility for subsequent chemical treatments [20]. Secondly, the ultrasonic treatment of cellulose in a phosphoric acid medium further deconstructs the molecular chains of cellulose using the cavitation effect induced by ultrasound [21]. Concurrently, the acidic environment of the phosphoric acid facilitates the hydrolysis of cellulose, yielding sugar intermediates that are more readily converted during pyrolysis [22]. Subsequently, cellulose undergoes a drying process designed to remove water, reducing energy consumption during pyrolysis and ensuring a stable chemical treatment environment. Lastly, cellulose is subjected to ultrasonication in a sodium hydroxide solution with a catalyst to promote deacetylation through the catalytic effect of the strong base [23]. This step further disrupts the crystalline structure of cellulose, enhancing its chemical reactivity during the pyrolysis process. Through systematic pretreatment of cellulose, discernible changes relative to the original sample are evident, as illustrated in scanning electron microscope (SEM) Fig. 2 a and b. The pristine cellulose displays a relatively smooth surface and a more intact structure. However, following the pretreatment process, the cellulose surface undergoes significant erosion, losing its smooth appearance, and the structure experiences pronounced damage, revealing diverse voids and cracks. These alterations in surface and structure lead to a substantial increase in surface roughness. Upon scrutinizing the cellulose surface for the presence of tiny particulate matter using energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) in Fig. 2c and d, it becomes evident that Fe and Al are uniformly distributed on the cellulose surface. This observation suggests that the catalyst is uniformly attached to the cellulose particles after the pretreatment. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of both pristine and pretreated cellulose revealed the presence of three distinct peaks at 2θ = 16°, 22°, and 34°, corresponding to the (101), (002), and (040) crystal planes in the cellulose crystal structure, respectively. Fig. 3 a illustrates a noticeable reduction in the intensity of all peaks in the pretreated cellulose. To quantitatively assess the change in cellulose crystallinity, the crystallinity index (CrI) was calculated using Segal's formula [24] in Eq. (1): (1) C r I ( % ) = I 002 − I a m I 002 * 100 % Where I002 and Iam represent the characteristic peak intensities of the cellulose crystal structure at 2θ = 16° and 22°, respectively, calculating with Segal's formula, the crystallinity index of pristine cellulose was 55.74 %, whereas that of pretreated cellulose was 33.68 %. A comparison of the crystallinity indices between the pristine and pretreated cellulose indicated a significant reduction in cellulose crystallinity due to the pretreatment. Furthermore, in XRD pattern analysis, the presence of these oxides on the surface of the pretreated cellulose was detected. Although their characteristic diffraction peaks overlapped with those of cellulose, causing a slight shift, the overall impact on the crystalline structure's integrity and the degree of crystallinity was found to be minor. Subsequently, the functional groups within the cellulose were characterized using Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR). The resulting FT-IR spectra, as depicted in Fig. 3b, exhibit distinct absorption peaks. The broad peaks in the 3200–3500 cm-1 range correspond to the vibrational modes of hydroxyl groups (-OH) associated with water molecules [25], indicating the presence of bound water within the cellulose matrix. Meanwhile, the absorption peaks at 2900 cm-1, 1650 cm-1, and 1430 cm-1 are ascribed to the vibrations of C-H, C=O, and C-O-H bonds within the cellulose backbone, respectively [26]. Notably, the absorption peak at 898 cm-1 is indicative of the in-plane stretching of the C-O-C bond in the β-glycosidic linkage. In contrast, the peak at 997 cm-1 is associated with the stretching of the C-OH bond at the C6 position of glucose. A comparative analysis of the FT-IR spectra in Fig. 3b reveals a pronounced reduction in the intensity of the absorption peaks for the pretreated cellulose samples. Furthermore, in conjunction with the observed decrease in the cellulose CrI, these findings collectively support the hypothesis that molecular chain scission may have occurred during pretreatment, leading to a reduction in crystallinity. Additionally, the FTIR analysis may exhibit additional absorption peaks due to Fe and Al oxides. However, since the vibrations of metal-oxygen bonds predominantly occur in the lower wavenumber range and do not coincide with the characteristic absorption bands of cellulose's organic functional groups, their effect on the FTIR characterization is minimal. This indicates that FTIR analysis can still accurately reflect the chemical composition and the state of functional groups in cellulose, even in the presence of iron and aluminium oxides introduced during the pretreatment process. Secondly, the pyrolysis behaviour of cellulose was elucidated using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), as depicted in Fig. 3c. During TGA, iron and aluminium oxides, characterized by their exceptionally high decomposition temperatures exceeding 1200 °C, remain stable within the pyrolysis temperature range typically utilized for cellulose below 350 °C. Consequently, their decomposition is minimal, and their influence on the thermogravimetric profile of cellulose is negligible. Thus, the results indicated that the pyrolysis onset temperature for the pretreated cellulose was lower than that of the untreated cellulose. Below 150 °C, both types of cellulose exhibited mass loss, which is attributed to the evaporation of water and the volatilization of small molecular components within the cellulose matrix. Subsequently, cellulose entered a rapid pyrolysis phase, during which the pretreated cellulose achieved its peak pyrolysis rate at 330 °C. Notably, the cellulose mass loss rate significantly decelerated after 350 °C, suggesting that this temperature largely completed the rapid phase of cellulose pyrolysis. Since the pretreated cellulose demonstrated the highest pyrolysis rate at 330 °C, this temperature was selected as the experimental pyrolysis temperature for the study. 3.2 Characterization of the catalyst The catalyst was synthesized hydrothermal, as outlined in the catalyst preparation. Subsequent rapid pyrolysis experiments on cellulose revealed that the optimum content of D-Allose in the bio-oil was achieved when the molar ratio of Al to Fe in the catalyst was 1:5. Consequently, the Al1-Fe5 nano-catalyst was chosen for detailed analysis. The SEM image of the catalyst, as illustrated in Fig. 4 a, reveals a distinctive irregular shape characterized by notable folds and pores, forming a unique nanoflower structure. This intricate and porous architecture profoundly influences the catalyst's performance and is the foundation for its exceptional catalytic efficacy in facilitating cellulose pyrolysis reactions. The irregular shapes, folds, and pores on the catalyst surface are pivotal in augmenting the contact area between the catalyst and cellulose. Nanoflower structures are of particular significance, which further amplify surface accessibility, providing an expanded array of adsorption and reaction sites for cellulose molecules. This highly intricate and porous structure generates an abundance of active sites, markedly enhancing the catalytic prowess of the catalyst in cellulose pyrolysis reactions. Fig. 4b depicts the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the Al1-Fe5 nano-catalyst. The pattern reveals characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ=30.09°, 35.44°, 43.07°, 56.96°, and 62.55°, corresponding to (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) nanocrystalline facets of standard Fe3O4 nanoparticles (JCPDS. Card 85-1436), respectively. This observation unequivocally establishes the presence of Fe3O4 nanoparticles in the synthesized catalysts. Simultaneously, characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ= 25.72°, 35.38°, 43.6°, 46.43°, and 61.76° were assigned to the (012), (104), (113), (202), and (018) crystalline facet diffraction peaks of Al2O3 (JCPDS. Card 75-0785), confirming the concurrent presence of Al2O3 nanoparticles on the catalyst. A comprehensive analysis of the XRD patterns establishes that the Al1-Fe5 nano-catalyst comprises nano-sized particles of both Fe3O4 and Al2O3. Upon analyzing the FT-IR spectra of the catalysts employed in Fig. 4c, it was observed that the spectra displayed broad peaks in the range of 3200–3500 cm-1, corresponding to the hydroxyl (-OH) group of the water molecule, indicating the presence of bound water in the catalysts. Additionally, absorption peaks at 3329 cm-1, 1621 cm-1, and 1085 cm-1 were identified, attributable to the -NH2 bond stretching vibration, the C=O bond stretching vibration, and the C-N bond stretching vibration in urea [27]. Furthermore, an absorption peak at 1435 cm-1 corresponded to the C-O-H bending vibration in CH3-OH [28]. These findings suggest the inclusion of urea and methanol in the catalyst composition. To delve deeper into the catalytic mechanism of the cellulose pyrolysis catalyst, analyze the valence compositions of metal elements before and after the catalyst reaction using XPS. The XPS data analysis in Fig. 5 a demonstrates that the relative increase in the C 1s peak during cellulose pyrolysis corresponds to an augmented presence of nonvolatile carbon structures within the biochar. This observation is attributed to the carbonization process of cellulose polymer chains, which, following dehydration and dehydrogenation reactions, break down into smaller hydrocarbon molecules. These molecules then undergo further carbonization, resulting in the formation of stable carbon structures. Concurrently, the attenuation of the O 1s peak corresponds to the decomposition of oxygen-containing functional groups within the cellulose, such as hydroxyl and carbonyl groups. Upon pyrolysis, these groups decompose, releasing water vapour and other volatile oxides and reducing the relative oxygen content in the biochar. Furthermore, the diminished intensity of the XPS peaks for elements Fe and Al could be ascribed to the overshadowing effect of the intensified carbon signals during carbonization. This enhancement may partially obscure the signals from these metals, potentially complicating the precise quantification of their elemental content. Despite the alterations in the biochar's chemical composition throughout the pyrolysis process, the elemental composition of the Al1-Fe5 nanocatalyst has been found to remain constant during the reaction. This stability substantiates the catalyst's chemical and thermal robustness under the pyrolysis conditions. In the XPS patterns of Fe 2p [29], the two peaks primarily situated at 710.99 eV and 724.43 eV corresponded to Fe 2p1/2 and Fe 2p2/3 for Fe2+, while the peaks at 713.87 eV and 727.31 eV corresponded to Fe 2p1/2 and Fe 2p2/3 for Fe3+, which was located in Fig. 5b. This indicated the presence of both Fe2+ and Fe3+ in the catalysts. Additionally, two satellite peaks at 718.52 eV and 731.32 eV were observed in Fe 2p. In Fig. 5c, a comparison of Fe2+ and Fe3+ content before and after the catalyst use revealed that, before use, the Fe2+ content was 48.85 % and Fe3+ content was 24.2 %. After the reaction, the Fe2+ content increased to 69.27 %, while the Fe3+ content decreased to 14.6 %. This suggests that the Fe3+ ions in the catalyst have an oxidizing effect on the cellulose pyrolysis process, leading to a substantial reduction of Fe3+ ions to Fe2+ ions. In contrast, the XPS of Al 2p did not exhibit significant changes before and after the reaction, as shown in Fig. 5d and e. The catalysts' surface area and porosity parameters were assessed through N2-temperature programmed desorption (N2-TPD), and the results are depicted in Fig. 6 a. Analysis of the isothermal adsorption and desorption curves revealed the presence of an adsorption hysteresis loop in the middle section and a raised posterior section with capillary coalescence across the entire pressure (P/Po) range. This characteristic indicates porous adsorption, akin to the type IV isotherm typically observed in mesoporous materials [30]. Furthermore, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm displayed a smaller H4 hysteresis line associated with capillary condensation in narrow fissure-like pores and irregularly shaped internal voids within the catalyst [31]. This suggests the coexistence of both microporous and mesoporous structures in the catalyst. Moreover, the particle size distribution of the catalyst, as illustrated in Fig. 6a, indicates that the catalyst is primarily characterized by mesopores, with a relatively lower abundance of micropores and macropores. The calculated average pore size of the catalyst was 10.142 nm, with a porosity of 0.017 cm³/g. These findings affirm that the catalyst synthesized in this experiment is indeed a nano-catalyst. Ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was employed to analyze acid site strength and distribution in the catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 6b, depicting the NH3 desorption spectra of the catalysts [32]. The distribution of acid sites on the catalysts was determined based on the NH3 desorption temperature—the broad peaks in the figure result from ammonia binding to different Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. The NH3-TPD profiles revealed a single broad peak across the temperature range of 100 °C to 400 °C, which underscores the presence of a diverse array of acidic sites with varying strengths and types on the catalyst surface. Based on the desorption temperatures, these sites can be differentiated into two categories: weak acidic sites, characterized by desorption temperatures below 200 °C [33], and medium-strong acidic sites, which desorb between 200 °C and 450 °C [34]. This classification allows us to deduce that the catalyst surface is populated with weak and medium-strong acidic sites. The heterogeneity of acidic sites is pivotal for their mediate reactions' catalytic activity and selectivity. These sites can offer protons or accept electron pairs with varying intensities, thereby influencing the adsorption of reactants and the pathways of the catalytic reactions. Through NH3-TPD analysis, we quantitatively assessed the total acid content of the Al1-Fe5 nanocatalysts, determining it to be 0.58 mmol (NH3)/g. This quantitative assessment indicates that the catalyst surfaces are enriched with Brønsted weak acidic sites and a combination of Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites. While Brønsted acidic sites can release protons (H +), Lewis acid sites are adept at accepting electron pairs. This rich diversity and abundance of acidic sites are critical factors that contribute to the high activity and selectivity of the catalysts in facilitating reactions. Finally, the stability of the catalyst was assessed through TG analysis. In Fig. 6c, the thermal decomposition of the catalyst revealed three distinct stages. In the initial stage, at a temperature of 106 °C, the catalyst mass decreased by 17.9 % wt. This decrease can be attributed to the evaporation of methanol and some of the water in the catalyst. In the second stage, with the temperature rising from 106 °C to 150 °C, the catalyst again experienced a mass decrease due to the release of bound water. Lastly, as the temperature reached 250 °C, the urea in the catalyst underwent decomposition, resulting in a total weight loss of the catalyst reaching 54.2 % wt. Notably, the mass of the catalyst exhibited minimal changes beyond 250 °C, indicating that the catalyst remained stable throughout cellulose pyrolysis and effectively catalyzed the process to completion. 3.3 Pyrolysis of cellulose 3.3.1 Bio-oil In this study, we utilized gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) to conduct a comprehensive analysis of the bio-oil compositions generated from cellulose pyrolysis, employing catalysts with varying molar ratios of Al to Fe. A systematic assessment of the impact of Al-Fe catalysts on the distribution of pyrolysis products revealed that the yields of biochar, bio-oil, and gas remained relatively consistent, with bio-oil yield being the highest, biochar the second, and gas yield the lowest (as shown in Fig. 7 a). Further analysis (detailed in Fig. 7b) indicated that the molar ratio of Al to Fe significantly influenced the composition of the pyrolysis products. When the Al molar ratio was fixed at 1, the sugar yield increased initially with the increment of the Fe molar ratio but declined after reaching a Fe molar ratio of 7. This suggests that iron content plays a dual role in sugar production: an optimal level of Fe enhances sugar yield, while an excess may be detrimental. Experiments confirmed that by fine-tuning the Al-Fe molar ratio in the catalyst, particularly from 1:1 to 1:5, the bio-oil sugar content could be substantially elevated. At the same time, the levels of aldehydes, alcohols, and other compounds were reduced. Notably, at an Al: Fe molar ratio of 1:5, the sugar yield peaked at 56.3 %, with the D-Allose yield notably high at 50.69 % (Fig. 7c). In contrast, adjusting the Al: Fe molar ratio to 5:1 resulted in a sugar yield decrease of 42 %, with a relative increase in the proportion of aldehydes, alcohols, hydrocarbons, and other substances. We observed an inverse relationship between the increase in sugar content and the decrease in aldehyde and alcohol content, which may be closely associated with the chemical properties of Fe, acting as a weak acid to promote the conversion of sugars to aldehydes and alcohols. We designed control experiments with Fe catalysts devoid of Al to delve deeper into the specific effects of different catalysts on sugar yields. The results demonstrated that the catalyst containing only Fe markedly reduced the sugar yield. Moreover, when the Al to Fe molar ratio was 5:1, the sugar content was lower than that at the 1:5 ratio, further validating the substantial influence of Fe content on sugar yield. The main compounds released upon GC–MS analysis of bio-oil obtained from cellulose are in Table S1. In light of the pyrolysis results, as mentioned above, a detailed analysis of the sugars with the highest content in the bio-oil was conducted. As illustrated in Fig. 6, the yield of D-Allose in the bio-oil exhibits an increasing trend with the percentage of Fe content in the Al: Fe catalyst. However, it was observed that excessively high or low proportions of Fe impede D-Allose generation. The outcomes revealed that when the catalyst's molar ratio of Al to Fe was 1:5, the highest D-Allose yield reached an impressive 50.69 %. This yield is surprising compared to other treatments in Table 1 . This phenomenon can be rationalized by the increased Fe content in the Al-Fe catalyst, leading to a higher Fe3+ content, consequently elevating the acidic oxidation sites [42]. Simultaneously, Fe3+ induces the cleavage of the β-O-4 glycosidic bond in cellulose during the pyrolysis process [43], facilitating the conversion of cellulose to glucose and promoting the isomerization of the -OH group at the C-3 position of glucose to form D-Allose. However, an excessive Fe content in the catalysts results in an overaccumulation of acidic sites, leading to the further oxidation of saccharides into aldehydes and alcohols and reducing the yield of D-Allose [44,45]. This underscores the crucial role of modulating Fe content in the catalyst to ensure effective glycosidic bond breaking while avoiding excessive oxidation reactions, thereby enhancing the selective yield of D-Allose. 3.3.2 Bio-char SEM morphological characterization of the bio-char produced by the rapid pyrolysis of cellulose revealed distinctive features in Fig. 8 a. The bio-char, post-rapid pyrolysis treatment exhibited a porous structure composed of agglomerated blobs, displaying numerous folds and holes prominently visible on the surface of the blobs. The formation of these tiny spheres is likely a result of the robust carbonization reaction occurring during the pyrolysis coking process of cellulose. Simultaneously, the porous structure observed in the bio-char can be ascribed to the escape of gases generated from the decomposition of cellulose under high-temperature conditions. Fig. 8d illustrates the XRD pattern of the bio-char resulting from the rapid pyrolysis of cellulose. The bio-char exhibits crystallographic diffraction peaks at (012), (104), (113), (202), and (018) corresponding to Al2O3 (JCPDS. Card 75-0785) at 2θ= 25.72°, 35.38°, 43.6°, 46.43°, and 61.76°. Additionally, characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 24.12°, 34.11°, 35.6°, 49.41°, 54°, and 62.37° are observed, aligning with the standard Fe2O3 nanoparticles (JCPDS. Card 89-0597), featuring (012), (104), (110), (024), (116), and (214) nano-crystalline surfaces, respectively. This indicates that the bio-char derived from cellulose pyrolysis contains nano-Fe2O3. In summary, the biochar is confirmed to contain nanoparticles of both Fe2O3 and Al2O3. In Fig. 8e, the bio-char produced through cellulose pyrolysis was comprehensively analyzed using FT-IR. The findings indicated a thorough pyrolysis process of cellulose, leading to the absence of characteristic functional groups associated with cellulose in biochar. Subsequent analysis revealed that the remaining absorption peaks could be attributed to the absorption phenomenon resulting from the carbon elements generated during the pyrolysis process. 3.4 Reaction pathway of model compounds The pyrolysis of cellulose is a multi-step depolymerization process, the intricacies of which are depicted in Fig. 9 a as the proposed mechanism for the selective pyrolysis of cellulose in the presence of Alx-Fey nanocatalysts to produce D-Allose [39]. D-Allose shares a chemical structure with D-glucose, differing as a stereoisomer at the C-3 position, suggesting that glucose is a pivotal intermediate in generating D-Allose (referred to as intermediate A). NH3-TPD desorption characterization of the catalyst exposed diverse acidic sites on the catalyst surface. These sites are capable of selectively oxidizing the hydroxyl group at the C-3 position of intermediate A during pyrolysis, facilitating the formation of intermediate B. Post-reaction characterization of the catalysts via XPS indicated a reduction in Fe3+ content and a concomitant increase in Fe2+ content. This finding implies that the catalyst actively engages in the cellulose pyrolysis reaction, serving an oxidative function. It is thus inferred that the oxidative potential of Fe3+ is instrumental in the cleavage of cellulose chains to yield intermediate A and in the complete oxidation of the hydroxyl group at the C-3 position of intermediate A, leading to the formation of intermediate B. To elucidate the role of Al in the catalysts further, a comparative analysis of Fig. 9c and 9d indicates minimal variation in Fe2+ and Fe3+ contents for the Al0-Fe5 catalyst before and after the reaction. In contrast, a marked decrease in Fe3+ and a corresponding increase in Fe2+ were observed in the Al1-Fe5 catalyst. This observation suggests that Al's role in the Alx-Fey nanocatalysts is predominantly to enhance the conversion of Fe3+ to Fe2+. Moreover, cellulose undergoes dehydration during pyrolysis, yielding small molecule intermediates [46]. Intermediate B can exploit the generated water molecules to reduce the carbonyl group at its C-3 position to -OH through a hydration reaction, thereby completing the isomerization of glucose at the C-3 position to produce D-Allose. We thus propose a potential step in the pyrolysis of cellulose to generate D-Allose in the presence of Alx-Fey nanocatalysts. 3.5 Potential industrial applications D-Allose is a rare monosaccharide with unique stereochemical properties that endow it with a broad spectrum of potential industrial applications. In the food industry, D-Allose's combination of low caloric content and high sweetness makes it an ideal sucrose substitute, particularly for developing dietary products tailored for health-conscious and diabetic consumers [47]. Its prebiotic properties also expand its utility in functional foods, promoting intestinal health and bolstering its market appeal. The pharmaceutical sector is witnessing a surge in demand for D-Allose, driven by its established bioactivity in anti-cancer and anti-diabetic therapies [48], paving the way for novel drug development avenues. Additionally, D-Allose's role as a stabilizer in vaccines and biologics highlights its importance in the biotechnology industry. In the cosmetic industry, D-Allose's moisturizing and antioxidant attributes render it a crucial component in anti-ageing product formulations, amplifying product efficacy and market competitiveness [49,50]. Lastly, the presence of Fe and Al oxides in biochar, while potentially restricting its direct use as a traditional adsorbent or soil amendment, actually introduces a novel application pathway for biochar—specifically, within the realm of metal recycling. In the context of the escalating global demand for metal resources, the recovery of metals from waste materials has gained significant importance. This recovery process not only mitigates the issue of resource scarcity but also represents a pivotal strategy for fostering a circular economy. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, this study successfully achieved the efficient pyrolytic conversion of cellulose to D-Allose using Al1-Fe5 nanocatalysts coupled with an innovative cellulose pretreatment technique. This approach presents a novel avenue for the high-value transformation of bio-oil. The experimental outcomes underscored the pivotal impact of catalyst ratios and pretreatment methods on enhancing D-Allose yield, with a peak yield of 50.69 % attained at an Al to Fe molar ratio of 1:5. Moreover, the presence of 14.35 % furfural in the bio-oil substantiates the diversity and significant economic potential of cellulose pyrolysis products. Future research will delve deeper into the catalytic mechanisms underlying cellulose pyrolysis to produce D-Allose. This endeavour aims to elucidate the conversion pathways and engineer more efficacious targeted strategies. Concurrently, catalyst design will be refined to augment catalytic performance and durability while curtailing production costs. Furthermore, we intend to investigate more cost-effective and environmentally benign cellulose pretreatment techniques. We aim to advance the process towards greater directionality, sustainability, and efficiency by exploring strategies to diminish the pyrolysis temperature. coredata.dc:description: This research has made significant advancements in the field of high-value bio-oil production, specifically focusing on the synthesis of the rare sugar D-Allose. Notably, synthesizing D-Allose through cellulose pyrolysis has long been challenging due to its high synthetic difficulty, which has limited related studies. By employing a one-pot synthesis approach using Alx-Fey nano-catalysts prepared through a unique cellulose pretreatment method, this experiment successfully achieved efficient generation of D-Allose during rapid pyrolysis. Systematic experimentation demonstrated that at 330 °C with the Al1-Fe5 nano-catalyst, the yield of D-Allose from cellulose pyrolysis reached an impressive 50.69 %, accompanied by a detection of 14.35 % furfural in the bio-oil. This breakthrough not only significantly contributes to the high-value utilization of bio-oil but also provides robust support for further development in this area. Simultaneously, the success of this research extends beyond high-value bio-oil utilization and makes a substantial impact on both the scientific community and industry.
coredata.dc:title: Effective catalytic conversion of cellulose pyrolysis into D-Allose via Al1-Fe5 nano-catalysts
